p.s: The article Hope of escape lost in translation written by Zia Haider Rahman and published in The Sunday Times on the 17th December 2016 is a text about language learning and its consequences for the integration of immigrant communities in Great Britain.
In the four paragraphs the author talks about her experiences and tries to convince the readers of her opinions.
The text is written in informal English and in a serious tone.
While in the first paragraph the governmental costs for translating services are mentioned, she explains the consequences of migrants not being integrated in the second one.

The third paragraph where we get to know more about her education she uses an Alliterationalliteration, repeating My parents (ll. 11-14), emphasizing that those intentions and aspirations were drawn mainly from her parents and how much they wanted her to have a good education.

When talking about celebrating diversity in paragraph four, she uses a metaphor saying But you don't learn to stand on your own two feet if someone is holding you up (ll. 18-19), wichwhich helps the reader understanding what exactly she means by being able to picture it.

Another thing that can be noticed is that Zia uses we and us multiple times, not only holding herself accountable for things she believes she can change, but also including the readers and appealing to them, making them feel responsible for the situation.
Zia wrote this article to convince and appeal to people, trying to get them to change something.
